page.title: 1974 Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships in Athletics

revision.text:
{{Infobox Athletics Championships |Name = I Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships |Logo = |Size = 200px |Colour = |Optional caption = |Host city = [[Maracaibo]], [[Venezuela]] {{flagicon|Venezuela}} |Dates = 12–15 December |Stadium = |Nations participating = 10 |Athletes participating = about 196 |Events = 36 |Records set = |Level = Junior |Previous = |Next = [[1976 Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships in Athletics|1976 Xalapa]] }} The 1st '''[[Central American and Caribbean Junior Championships]]''' was held in [[Maracaibo]], [[Venezuela]] on 12–15 December 1974, one and a half year after having already hosted the 4th [[1973 Central American and Caribbean Championships in Athletics|CAC senior championships]] in July 1973. ==Event summary== The athletes from Mexico gained most of the gold medals. In the total medal count, Venezuela equalizes the Mexican result, both countries gaining 21 each. In the under-20 men category, [[Anthony Husbands]], Trinidad and Tobago, won two gold (100m, 200m) and one silver medal (4 × 100 m relay), double gold was won by [[José Briano]] from Mexico (3000m, 5000m), and [[Carmelo Martínez (athlete)|Carmelo Martínez]] from Cuba (Long jump, Triple jump). In the under-20 women category, [[Dorothy Scott]], Jamaica, won three golds (100m, Long jump, 4 × 100 m relay), and [[Maureen Gottschalk]], Jamaica, gained two golds (200m, 4 × 400 m relay) and one bronze medal (400m). The event saw an early appearance of [[Ernesto Canto]], Mexico, won the gold medal in the men's 20 kilometre walk event at the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] held in Los Angeles, United States. He was successful in the [[10,000 metres track walk]] competition. Moreover, [[Luis Delís]] from [[Cuba]] won the [[Discus]] competition. He was going to win the bronze medal at the [[1980 Summer Olympics]] in Moscow, Soviet Union, as well as silver at the [[1983 World Championships in Athletics|1983 World Championships]] in Helsinki, Finland, and bronze at the [[1987 World Championships in Athletics|1987 World Championships]] in Rome, Italy. ==Medal summary== Medal winners are published by category: Junior A, Male, {{ Citation |work=Athletics Weekly |first= |date= |title=CENTRAL AMERICAN AND CARIBBEAN JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIPS (UNDER 20 MEN) |url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cacj.htm |publisher= |accessdate=August 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vDet7Fzo?url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cacj.htm |archivedate=December 24, 2010 |df= }} and Junior A, Female. {{ Citation | work = Athletics Weekly | first = | date = | title = CENTRAL AMERICAN AND CARIBBEAN JUNIOR CHAMPIONSHIPS (UNDER 20 WOMEN) | url = http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/cacjw.htm | publisher = | accessdate = August 8, 2011 }} {{Clear}} ===Male Junior A (under 20)=== {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event|columns=2}} |- |bgcolor = DDEEFF|[[100 metres]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Deutsches Stadion}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Dutchess Stadium | nickname = "The Dutch" | image = Dutchess Stadium 2.jpg | image_size = 275px | caption = August 2010 | location = 1500 Route 9D
[[Fishkill (town), New York|Town of Fishkill, NY]] 12524 | coordinates = {{coord|41|31|40.48|N|73|57|39.84|W|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = January 20, 1994{{cite news |title=Stadium Crew Breaks Ground Jan. 20|first=Christopher|last=Carter|url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%20Disk3/Amenia%20NY%20Harlem%20Valley%20Times/Amenia%20NY%20Harlem%20Valley%20Times%201994%20Jan%20-%20May%20grayscale.pdf/Amenia%20NY%20Harlem%20Valley%20Times%201994%20Jan%20-%20May%20grayscale%20-%200196.pdf|newspaper=Harlem Valley Times|date=January 27, 1994|accessdate=July 1, 2012|page=A12}} | opened = June 18, 1994{{cite news |title=The Old Ball Game Gets New Times at Bat|first=Robert|last=Hanley|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/19/nyregion/the-old-ball-game-gets-new-times-at-bat.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 19, 1994|accessdate=November 8, 2011}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Hudson Valley Stadium Corp. | operator = Hudson Valley Stadium Corp. | surface = Astro-Turf | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]8.3 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|8300000|1994}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Liscum McCormack VanVoorhis LLP{{cite web |title=Dutchess Stadium|url=http://lmvarchitects.com/project/dutchess-stadium/|publisher=Liscum McCormack VanVoorhis LLP|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} | structural engineer = [[Geiger Engineers]] | services engineer = Fellenzer Engineering LLP{{cite web |title=Sports & Recreational Facilities|url=http://www.fellp.com/sports.html|publisher=Fellenzer Engineering LLP|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} | general_contractor = Meyer Contracting Corporation{{cite web |title=Renegades Baseball Stadium|url=http://www.meyercontracting.com/renegades-stadium.html|publisher=Meyer Contracting Corporation|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Hudson Valley Renegades]] ([[New York–Penn League|NYPL]]) (1994–present)
[[Manhattan Jaspers baseball|Manhattan Jaspers]] ([[NCAA]]) (2015–present)
[[Hudson Valley Fort]] ([[Fall Experimental Football League|FXFL]]) (2015) | seating_capacity = 4,494 | dimensions = Left field: 325 feet
Center field: 400 feet
Right field: 325 feet }} '''Dutchess Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in the [[Fishkill (town), New York|town of Fishkill, New York]]. It opened in 1994 and holds 4,500 people. It is located on [[New York State Route 9D]]. Visible from the stadium is [[Fishkill Correctional Facility]] as well as [[Interstate 84 in New York|Interstate 84]]. Construction began in January 1994 and was ready for Opening Day in June 1994.{{cite web |title=Hudson Valley Renegades|first=Brian|last=Merzbach|url=http://www.ballparkreviews.com/hv/hv.htm|work=Ballpark Reviews|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} ==Uses== The stadium is primarily used for [[baseball]], as the home field of the [[Hudson Valley Renegades]] [[minor league]] baseball team, the short season-A level team of the [[Tampa Bay Rays]]. Each April the stadium hosts the Hudson Valley Baseball Classic between [[Marist Red Foxes|Marist College]] and the [[Army Black Knights|United States Military Academy]].{{Cite web |title=WRWD Hudson Valley Baseball Classic Set For April 24|url=http://www.goarmysports.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/040913aaa.html|publisher=Army Athletics|date=April 9, 2013|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} Besides baseball it is also used for weddings, catered events and concerts. The stadium hosts K104's annual KFest concert held in early June, as well as a rock concert, usually held in late August. Performing artists have included [[Akon]], [[Rihanna]], [[Fat Joe]], [[Counting Crows]], [[Collective Soul]], [[Wilco]], [[Def Leppard]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Drake (rapper)|Drake]] and [[Adam Lambert]], among others. On July 15, 2014, it was announced that [[Manhattan College]]'s baseball team will play all of their home competitions at Dutchess Stadium {{Cite web |title=Baseball to Play 2015 Home Games at Dutchess Stadium|url=http://www.gojaspers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=52438&SPID=5435&DB_LANG=C&ATCLID=209577623&DB_OEM_ID=12500|publisher=Manhattan College Athletics|date=July 15, 2014|accessdate=August 12, 2014}} The stadium's first [[American football|football]] tenant, the [[Hudson Valley Fort]] of the [[Fall Experimental Football League]], took up residence in the stadium in October 2015.{{cite news|title=Brawlers will be part of FXFL|url=http://www.vindy.com/news/2015/jul/16/fxfl-makes-things-official/|accessdate=July 16, 2015|work=Vindy.com|publisher=The Vindicator|date=July 16, 2015}} Some [[high school football]] playoff contests were also to be held at the stadium that year, but the stadium was later determined to be unsafe as a football venue and those games were canceled.{{cite web|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/story/sports/2015/11/04/hudson-valley-forts-season-finale-cancelled/75183060/?from=global&sessionKey=&autologin=|title=Hudson Valley Fort's season finale canceled|last=Haynes|first=Stephen|date=November 4, 2015|accessdate=November 20, 2015}} [[File:Dutchess Stadium, Fishkill, New York.jpg|thumb|Dutchess Stadium in 2009, taken from the seats behind home plate]] [[File:Dutchess Stadium - Main Stand.jpg|thumb|Dutchess Stadium, August 2010]] ==Features== In addition to concessions, the stadium features a kids area, which includes an ice cream shop and play areas. The entire field, excluding the pitchers mound and home plate area, was converted to [[Astro-Turf]] in the spring of 2014.{{cite news |title=Dutchess Stadium Turf Thrills Hudson Valley Renegades|first=Sean T.|last=McMann|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/article/20140405/SPORTS03/140402014/|newspaper=[[Poughkeepsie Journal]]|date=April 5, 2014|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Dutchess Stadium}} *[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t537&ymd=20100514&content_id=10036096&vkey=team1 Hudson Valley Renegades: Dutchess Stadium] *[http://www.ballparkreviews.com/hv/hv.htm Balkpark Reviews review of Dutchess Stadium] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2001/Wappingers_Falls/Hudson.htm Dutchess Stadium Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] *[http://www.baseballstadiumreviews.com/Stadium%20Home%20Pages/Single%20A%20Home%20Pages/Dutchess%20Stadium-HV%20Renegades.html Stadium Review and Photos of Dutchess Stadium] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110727134133/http://nycdwi.org/about/?mn=69 Dutchess Stadium and the Hudson Valley Renegades Review: A Wedding and a Ball Game] {{Manhattan College|state=autocollapse}} {{FXFL}} {{NYPL Ballparks}} {{Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{New York NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues in Dutchess County, New York]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Manhattan Jaspers baseball]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Fishkill, New York]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Hudson Valley Fort]] [[Category:American football venues in New York (state)]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} '''George Leer''' (1748 at [[Hambledon, Hampshire]] – 1 February 1812 at [[Petersfield, Hampshire]]) was a famous English [[cricket]]er who played for [[Hampshire county cricket teams|Hampshire]] in the time of the [[Hambledon Club]].
Leer began playing in the 1760s. His name has become almost synonymous with the now archaic long stop fielding position (i.e., directly behind the wicket-keeper) that was deemed so necessary in underarm days.
According to [[Arthur Haygarth]], Leer "was a good and successful bat, but was mostly famous as long-stop to [[Thomas Brett (cricketer)|Thomas Brett]]’s tremendous bowling in the Hambledon matches. He was always called "Little George", and was a fine singer, having a sweet counter-tenor voice.<ref name=S&B>[[Arthur Haygarth]], ''Scores & Biographies'', Volume 1 (1744-1826), Lillywhite, 1862</ref> In [[John Nyren]]’s book, he is stated to have been a native of Hambledon, but latterly he was a brewer, residing at Petersfield, where he died".<ref name=JN>[[Ashley Mote]], ''John Nyren's "The Cricketers of my Time"'', Robson, 1998</ref>
George Leer was a small man who made 44 known first-class appearances from the [[1772 English cricket season|1772 season]] to 1782.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153249/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1761.html#leer |date=10 October 2012 |title=From Lads to Lord's – profile }} * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/77/77390/77390.html CricketArchive]
==Further reading== * [[Ashley Mote]], ''The Glory Days of Cricket'', Robson, 1997 * [[David Underdown]], ''Start of Play'', Allen Lane, 2000
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leer, George}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:Hampshire cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:1748 births]] [[Category:1812 deaths]] [[Category:Hambledon cricketers]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Ratner Athletics Center | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[File:Ratner Athletic Center.jpg|250px|alt=a round brick building connected to two flat-surfaced buildings beyond a brick courtyard that has a bicyclist in it.]] | caption = | fullname = Gerald Ratner Athletics Center | former_names = | pushpin_map =United States Chicago Greater#USA Illinois#USA | pushpin_map_caption= | location = 5530 South Ellis Avenue
[[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]], Chicago, Illinois 60637 | coordinates = {{coord|41|47|38.87|N|87|36|6.48|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | broke_ground = October 28, 2000 (ceremonial groundbreaking) | built = | opened = September 29, 2003 (opened)
October 11, 2003 (dedicated) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Chicago]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = $51 million | suites = | architect = [[Cesar Pelli]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = OWP/P Structures | services engineer = | general_contractor = Walsh Construction Company, Inc., | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = {{convert|150000|sqft|sqm}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Chicago Maroons men's basketball|University of Chicago men's basketball]]
[[Chicago Maroons women's basketball|University of Chicago women's basketball]]
University of Chicago men's volleyball
University of Chicago women's volleyball
University of Chicago wrestling
University of Chicago men's swimming & diving
University of Chicago women's swimming & diving
University of Chicago Athletics Department }} The '''Gerald Ratner Athletics Center''' is a $51 million athletics facility within the [[University of Chicago]] campus in the [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]] on the [[South Side (Chicago)|South Side]] of [[Chicago]], Illinois in the United States. The building was named after University of Chicago alumnus, [[Gerald Ratner (lawyer)|Gerald Ratner]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20140620/NEWS04/130909947/lawyer-gerald-ratner-dies-at-100-crown-family-adviser-u-of-c-donor# |title=Crain's Chicago Business : Subscription Center |publisher=Chicagobusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} The architect of this suspension structure that is supported by [[Wikt:mast|mast]]s, [[Wire rope|cables]] and [[counterweight]]s was [[César Pelli]], who is best known as the architect of the [[Petronas Towers]]. The Ratner Athletics Center was approved for use in September 2003. The facility includes, among other things: a competition [[gym]]nasium, a multilevel fitness facility, an Olympic-sized [[swimming pool]], a multipurpose [[dance studio]], meeting room space, and athletic department offices. It serves as home to several of the university's athletic teams and has hosted numerous [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] regional and [[University Athletic Association]] conference championship events. Located at the southwest corner of Ellis Avenue and 55th Street, the Ratner Center has an award-winning design that substitutes a complex external mast and [[counterweight]] system for interior support devices to allow for large open-space areas inside the building. Cesar Pelli & Associates Inc. was credited as the design architect and OWP/P was the architect of record.{{cite web|url=http://www.risatech.com/showcase/msc/EAE2004/EAEAwards_RatnerAthleticsCenter.pdf|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-02|work=[[Modern Steel Construction]]|date=April 2004}} ==History== A ceremonial groundbreaking was held for the Ratner Center on October 28, 2000. The Ratner Center opened to the public on September 29, 2003, although it was not officially dedicated until [[homecoming]] weekend on October 11. The building, which represented a collaboration between Cesar Pelli & Associates and Chicago's OWP/P, was the first new athletic facility on the University of Chicago campus in 68 years.{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/031009/ratner-arch.shtml|title=Art of architecture expressed in new Ratner Center |accessdate=2010-05-02|date=2003-10-09|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=3|issue=2|author=Schuler, Peter}} It was a part of a $500 million University-wide capital improvement plan that occurred between 1999 and 2005. Part of the plan included the Pelli-designed parking structure across the street from the Athletics Center.{{cite book|title=AIA Guide To Chicago|edition=2nd|editor=Sinkevitch, Alice|year=2004|publisher=[[Harcourt Books]]|page=450}} The parking structure is named the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center Parking Structure.{{cite web|url=http://www3.owpp.com/content.cfm/uc_ratner_parking|title=The University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletics Center Parking Structure|accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=OWP/P|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011140437/http://owpp.com/content.cfm/uc_ratner_parking|archivedate=2010-10-11|df=}} The athletic center is known for its innovative asymmetrically supported cable-stayed structural system and S-shaped roofs. It is composed of a masted building to the north containing the Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool, a masted building to the south containing the gymnasia, and a central building containing the Bernard DelGiorno fitness center.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MpgmzOocCmMC&pg=PA152&lpg=PA152&dq=Myers-McLoraine+Swimming+Pool#v=onepage&q=Myers-McLoraine%20Swimming%20Pool&f=false|title=Pocket guide to Chicago architecture|author=McBrien, Judith Paine|publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]]|isbn=978-0-393-73155-2|page=152|year=2004|accessdate=2010-07-11}} [[File:Ratner Center map.PNG|thumb|left|Map of Ratner Center on the [[University of Chicago]] campus|alt=a street map with a portion of a block designated with red borders. The map also has several large green areas designating undeveloped land.]] Ratner, [[Bachelor of Philosophy|Ph.B.]],’35, [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]],’37, contributed $15 million toward the $51 million cost. He was a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] graduate and played for the [[baseball]] team during the time that the University participated in the [[Big Ten Conference]].{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/031009/ratner-profile.shtml|title=New athletics center named after ‘Red’ Ratner, a 1930s Chicago scholar, Maroon baseball player |accessdate=2010-05-02|date=2003-10-09|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=3|issue=2|author=Schonwald, Josh}} After graduating with a law degree, [[Order of the Coif]], he eventually founded his own law firm Gould & Ratner in 1949.{{cite web|url=http://www.gouldratner.com/attorneys-52.html|title=Gerald Ratner |accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=Gould & Ratner LLP.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407142611/http://www.gouldratner.com/attorneys-52.html |archivedate=2010-04-07}} [[Helen Myers McLoraine]], also an alumnus from the 1930s, contributed in excess of $5 million to fund the swimming pool.{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/001102/athletics-center.shtml|title=Architect Pelli, donor Ratner join celebration for new athletics center|accessdate=2010-05-05|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=20|issue=4|date=2000-11-02|author=Leovy, Jennifer}} Bernard DelGiorno — a gymnast with many degrees from the university: AB’54, AB’55, MBA’55 — has made numerous donations including a $5 million one in 2006 to fund athletic facilities as well as other infrastructure on campus. DelGiorno worked in industrial relations and personnel at a steel plant before becoming a [[stockbroker]] for [[Paine Webber]], which became a part of [[UBS Financial Services]].{{cite web|url=http://alumniandfriends.uchicago.edu/site/c.mjJXJ7MLIsE/b.4700041/k.99E9/Bernard_DelGiorno.htm|title=Bernard DelGiorno: Winner, 2007 Alumni Service Medal|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=The University of Chicago|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610011840/http://alumniandfriends.uchicago.edu/site/c.mjJXJ7MLIsE/b.4700041/k.99E9/Bernard_DelGiorno.htm|archivedate=2010-06-10|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/columns/story?columnist=greenberg_jon&id=4585864|title=Before it was normal: The University of Chicago celebrates the 40th anniversary of the return of football|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2009-10-21|publisher=[[ESPN]]|author=Greenberg, Jon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2007/9/30/delgiorno-pimps-our-football-field|title=DelGiorno pimps our football field|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2007-09-30|work=[[Chicago Maroon]]|author=Fratar, Kate|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328003755/http://chicagomaroon.com/2007/9/30/delgiorno-pimps-our-football-field/|archivedate=2012-03-28|df=}} ==Details== The building features the {{convert|50|m|yd|adj=on}} x {{convert|25|yd|m|adj=on}} Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool, which can be configured with up to 20 lanes in the 25-yard dimension and nine lanes in the 50-meter dimension. The pool's configuration is flexible with a moveable [[bulkhead (partition)|bulkhead]] which allows for simultaneous activities. It also has a pair of one-meter diving boards. The pool depth ranges from {{convert|4|to|13.5|ft|m}} in the shallow end and the diving well, respectively. The {{convert|24700|sqft|m2|0|adj=on}} competition [[natatorium]] features seating for 350 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.owpp.com/content.cfm/the_university_of_chicago_-_gerald_ratner_athletics_center|title=The University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-04|publisher=OWP/P}} The building also includes the Bernard DelGiorno fitness center. The DelGiorno Fitness Center facility occupies two levels of the Ratner center plus the rotunda area. In addition to a general fitness center, it includes a multipurpose dance studio; classroom and meeting room space; permanent and day lockers and locker rooms; the University of Chicago Athletics Hall of Fame; and the athletic department offices. The building also features a competition gym and auxiliary gym, both of which are available to recreational users. The competition gym, which is the southernmost building, accommodates practice and game site for varsity basketball, volleyball, and wrestling, but is convertible into two recreational courts. The auxiliary gym is multipurpose and can accommodate indoor soccer, as well as basketball, volleyball, and badminton. ==Use== The Ratner Center also serves as the home of the University of Chicago basketball, volleyball, and wrestling teams. The 1,658-seat competition gymnasium has played host to the 2004, 2007 and 2010 University Athletic Association Wrestling Championships and the 2006 NCAA Division III Great Lakes Regional Wrestling Championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.uaa.rochester.edu/Wrestling/2010_UAA_Wrestling_Results.pdf|title=2010 UAA Wrestling Championship|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=[[University of Rochester]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611072510/http://www.uaa.rochester.edu/Wrestling/2010_UAA_Wrestling_Results.pdf|archivedate=2011-06-11|df=}} The building also hosted the 2009 University Athletic Association Women's Volleyball Championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.com/sports/w-volley/recaps/110709aag.html|title=No. 3 Washington-St. Louis Falls To No. 4 Emory In UAA Championship: Washington University and Emory have met to decide 11 UAA Championships, and each of the last six|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2009-11-07|publisher=[[NCAA.org]]}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}} The Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool was the site of the 2005 University Athletic Association Swimming and Diving Championship. It also hosted swimming at the [[2006 Gay Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gaygameschicago.org/sports/sports.php?mgroup=Swimming|title=Gay Games VII Chicago 2006|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=Chicago Games, Inc.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206020547/http://www.gaygameschicago.org/sports/sports.php?mgroup=Swimming|archivedate=2010-12-06|df=}} The center is available to University and hospital faculty, staff, alumni, and retirees as well as their spouses and children on a paid membership basis and registered students for free.{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratner-overview.htm|title=Physical Education and Athletics: Overview|accessdate=2010-06-04|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080616150245/http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratner-overview.htm |archivedate = June 16, 2008}} {{Asof|2010}},{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/physed/freshman-packet.pdf|title=Fitness and Swimming Placement Test Information|accessdate=2010-06-04|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609155727/http://athletics.uchicago.edu/physed/freshman-packet.pdf|archivedate=2010-06-09|df=}} the University of Chicago is one of the few remaining universities in the United States to have a swimming requirement for its undergraduate degree program. Aside from the military service academies and a few of the [[Ivy League]] schools only a half dozen Universities had such a requirement as of 2006. The swimming pool is the location of the administration of the two-lap requirement.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2006/5/18/to-sink-or-swim-test-must-stay |title=To sink or swim: Test must stay |accessdate=2010-05-05 |date=2006-05-18 |author=Katz, Joe |work=[[Chicago Maroon]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107033547/http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2006/5/18/to-sink-or-swim-test-must-stay |archivedate=January 7, 2010 }} The facilities memberships are available to students as well as University and [[University of Chicago Medical Center|hospital]] faculty, staff, alumni and retirees, as well as spouses and children. Registered students' memberships are free. The building is complemented at the University by its predecessors the [[Henry Crown Field House]] and the modern incarnation of [[Stagg Field]], which will continue to augment the athletic facilities needs of the campus patrons. Features of the indoor Henry Crown Field House include a 200-meter indoor running track; [[racquetball]], [[American handball|handball]] and [[Squash (sport)|squash]] courts; multipurpose courts; a multipurpose room; and cardiovascular and weight training equipment. The Stagg Field outdoor complex includes a 400-meter track, eight [[tennis courts]], and fields for [[baseball]], [[softball]], [[American football]] and [[soccer]].{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/030925/ratner.shtml|title=Ratner will open doors to University community on Monday |volume=23|issue=1|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2003-09-25|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|author=Hilbert, Dave}} ==Design== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = Ratner Center's Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = 20090311 Ratner Center.jpg | width1 = 165 | alt1 = Ground-level view diagonally across an intersection of a building with several tall white poles | caption1 = | image2 = 20100507 Ratner Center pool roof and masts.JPG | width2 = 165 | alt2 = view from above of the roof of a curved roof of a building with tall white poles and various cables connecting them | caption2 = }} The construction employed {{convert|2000|ST|t LT|0|lk=on}} of steel. The {{convert|2000000|lbs|kg|0|adj=on}} roof of the gym is supported by a pair of {{convert|125|ft|m|adj=on}} steel masts. The pool's roof is supported by three masts. Each mast is composed of three {{convert|18|in|cm|0|adj=on}} diameter steel hollow structural sections (HSS) filled with high-strength concrete that are arranged in a tapered tied-column configuration. The German-import masts are united by 120 high-strength steel [[Wire rope|cables]] that total approximately {{convert|6500|ft|m|0}} in length. They are inclined at a 10 [[Degree (angle)|degree]] angle from vertical.{{cite web|url=http://cedb.asce.org/cgi/WWWdisplay.cgi?0206170|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813080842/http://cedb.asce.org/cgi/WWWdisplay.cgi?0206170|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-08-13|title=Jet Grout Columns in Mixed Profile to Control Foundation Settlement Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=[[American Society of Civil Engineers]]}} Each tapered composite mast that supports the flattened S-shaped roof girders is supported by 15 splaying cables; 9 fore-stay cables and 6 backstay cables. During construction, the masts were filled with {{convert|10000|psi|Pa|lk=on}} cast-in-place concrete using innovative pumping techniques. Concrete counterweights totaling {{convert|2500|cuyd|m3|0}} — with some as large as {{convert|50|by|25|by|13|ft|m}} — counteract the weight of the roof from below the ground. The masts and counterweights are likened as external form-giving elements to [[flying buttress]]es in [[gothic architecture]], which predominates the campus' architecture. The building is said to interpret gothic architecture through structural [[expressionism]]. The exterior support design made the interior space more receptive to open natural lighting and more accommodating for free movement. {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header = Ratner Center gymnasium | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = 20071123 Ratner Center.jpg | width1 = 180 | alt1 = Ground-level view of a building with white poles sticking up from its sides and with trees in autumn colors in front of it | caption1 = | image2 = 20100507 Ratner Center gymnasium roof and masts.JPG | width2 = 165 | alt2 = View from above of a building with white poles sticking up from its sides and the cables connecting them. A taller building is in the background and a connected brick building is visible on its right. | caption2 = }} The roof design incorporated multi-level splayed cables so that the structural roof members could form a {{convert|33|in|cm|1|adj=on}} deep uniformly curved roof plane. The roof members are curved and shallow. They support 7 {{convert|2|in|cm|1|adj=on}} thick {{convert|25|ft|m|1|adj=on}} metal roof deck spans between the roof girders. The W33x169 girders are cold bent with reverse curves to multiple radii. The curved roof planes are suspended from German "full-lock" steel cables and include three outer layers of interlocking Z-shaped wires designed to minimize water infiltration and corrosion. The engineering of the masts was complicated because stability was so important to the overall design success of the suspension structure. Mast displacements could significantly alter cable length and tension and redistribute loads through the superstructure contrary to design. The key to successful design was control of the [[Foundation (engineering)|foundation]] settlement. The sites natural underlying subsurface conditions were stiff silty [[clay]] below a medium dense sand layer, which was determined to be too accommodating to settlement to host the structure. Ground improvement, consisting of triple-fluid jet grouting, was performed to reduce the compressibility of the silty clay, stiffen the sand deposit and provide a desirable shallow foundation system. This site marked the first time that these geotechnical ground improvement techniques were employed. ==Reception== The facility's engineering and design has earned it awards from the [[American Council of Engineering Companies]], the [[American Institute of Steel Construction]], and the [[Consulting Engineers Council of Illinois]].{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratnercenter.htm|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center |accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=University of Chicago Department of Physical Education & Athletics |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080516134320/http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratnercenter.htm |archivedate = May 16, 2008}} The building earned a Merit Award in the category of new buildings in the $30 million and over category in the [[National Council of Structural Engineers Associations]] 2004 Excellence in Structural Engineering Awards program.{{cite web|url=http://www.structuremag.org/archives/2005/August+2005/Gerald-Ratner-Athletics-Center.pdf|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-04|date=August 2005|author=Eckmann, David E.|work=[[Structure (magazine)|Structure]]|page=40}} The building earned the 2003 Outstanding Civil Engineering Achievement of the Year award by the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]] and the 2004 Project of the Year Overall by ''[[Midwest Construction News]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecslimited.com/ProjectDetail.cfm?id=56|title=University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletic Center, Chicago, IL|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=ECS Corporate Services, LLC|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626172735/http://www.ecslimited.com/ProjectDetail.cfm?id=56|archivedate=2009-06-26|df=}} ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/facilities-ratnercenter.htm Official webpage] * [http://www.structuremag.org/archives/2005/August%202005/Gerald-Ratner-Athletics-Center.pdf ''Structure Magazine'' archived news article]{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} * [http://www.modernsteel.com/Uploads/Issues/April_2004/30728_EAE_ratner.pdf from modernsteel.com] {{coord|41.79413|N|87.60180|W|source:placeopedia|display=title}} {{Clear}} {{UChicago|campus}} {{Chicago Maroons men's basketball navbox}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Sports venues in Chicago]] [[Category:University of Chicago]] [[Category:Chicago Maroons men's basketball]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Chicago]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Chicago]] [[Category:Wrestling venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Illinois]] [[Category:High-tech architecture]] [[Category:Suspension structures]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:César Pelli buildings]] [[Category:Health clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Illinois]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Illinois]]

Bollin Eric | image3 = File:Owner Mr Abdulla BuHaleeba.svg | alt3 = Orange | caption3 = Zindabad }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Hardwicke Stakes''' is a [[Group races|Group 2]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in Great Britain open to horses aged four years or older. It is run at [[Ascot Racecourse|Ascot]] over a distance of 1 mile 3 furlongs and 211 yards (2,406 metres), and it is scheduled to take place each year in June. ==History== The event is named in honour of the [[Charles Yorke, 5th Earl of Hardwicke|5th Earl of Hardwicke]], who served as the [[Master of the Buckhounds]] in the 19th century. It was established in 1879, and it was originally open to horses aged three or older. The last three-year-old to win was Helioscope in 1949. The Hardwicke Stakes is now held on the final day of the five-day Royal Ascot meeting. The leading horses often return to the venue to compete in the following month's [[King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes]]. The first to win both races in the same year was [[Aureole (horse)|Aureole]] in 1954, and the most recent was [[Harbinger (horse)|Harbinger]] in 2010. ==Records== '''Most successful horse (3 wins):''' * [[Tristan (horse)|Tristan]] – ''1882, 1883, 1884'' '''Leading [[jockey]] (7 wins):''' * [[Lester Piggott]] – ''Elopement (1955), St Paddy (1961), Karabas (1970), Relay Race (1974), Meneval (1977), Critique (1982), Jupiter Island (1985)'' * [[Pat Eddery]] – ''Charlie Bubbles (1975), Orange Bay (1976), Dihistan (1986), Assatis (1989), Rock Hopper (1991, 1992), Posidonas (1998)'' '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (11 wins):''' * [[Michael Stoute|Sir Michael Stoute]] – ''Dihistan (1986), Rock Hopper (1991, 1992), Maraahel (2006, 2007), Harbinger (2010), Sea Moon (2012), Telescope (2014), Snow Sky (2015), Dartmouth (2016), Crystal Ocean (2018)'' ==Winners since 1980== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! revision.comment: Removed the "Strongman" tag by properly tagging the reference.
revision.text:
'''Keg-tossing''' (or '''keg toss''') is a [[sport]] that involves the heaving of a standard 15.5 gallon beer [[keg]]. Most people would refer to this type of keg as a "half-keg" or "half-barrel." The keg must be completely emptied before it should be tossed to avoid injuries. There are many different types of keg-tossing, as it is practiced throughout the world. In [[Ireland]], the keg is typically thrown over upwards and the height of the toss determines the winner.
The newest way to toss a keg combines techniques of both the discus and [[hammer throw]]. This updated form of keg-tossing does not require the athlete to toss the keg high, rather they are required to try to throw it the farthest distance. Athletes are given three attempts to throw the keg and the winner is determined by measuring the distance tossed. The one who throws the keg the furthest wins.
The basic technique for tossing the keg involves swinging the keg in a pendulum like manner and releasing the keg when it is at its apex. A more experienced athlete uses a spin method similar to a hammer throw. The keg is again released when it is at its apex, allowing for the maximum distance.
==Strongman competitions== In competitive [[strongman (strength athlete)|strongman]] competitions, such as at the [[World's Strongest Man]] competition, competitors throw kegs of increasing weights, and the keg is generally thrown overhead and to the rear of the thrower, and must be thrown over the top of a high bar. The competitors are scored based on how many kegs they can throw over the bar in the least amount of time. In this category, the world record is held by [[Brian Shaw (strongman)|Brian Shaw]] who threw a 15 kg keg over a 7.25 m bar in 2016.<ref>http://theworldsstrongestman.com/commerce-worlds-strongest-man-2016-roundup/</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Games of physical skill]] [[Category:Individual sports]] [[Category:Throwing sports]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Laird Q. Cagan Stadium | nickname = The Farm | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = Maloney Field at Laird Q. Cagan Stadium | former names = Maloney Field (1973–2007) | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = 641 Nelson Road
[[Stanford, California|Stanford, CA]] 94305 | location = | coordinates = {{Coord|37.4331017|-122.1580511|display=title}} | type = [[Soccer-specific stadium]] | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1973|08|15}} | renovated = 1997, 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Stanford University]] | operator = [[Stanford University]] | surface = [[Cynodon dactylon|Bermuda rye blend]] | scoreboard = [[Daktronics]] | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 2,952 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = 115 x 75 yards | field_shape = Rectangular | acreage = 4 | volume = | tenants = [[Stanford Cardinal men's soccer]]
[[Stanford Cardinal women's soccer]]
[[Stanford Cardinal women's lacrosse]] | embedded = | website = {{URL|gostanford.com/sports/2013/4/17/208446870.aspx}} | publictransit = {{rail-interchange|caltrain|}} [[California Avenue station|California Avenue Station]] }} '''Maloney Field at Laird Q. Cagan Stadium''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] on the campus of [[Stanford University]] in [[Stanford, California]]. The stadium hosts the [[Stanford Cardinal]] [[Stanford Cardinal men's soccer|men's]] and [[Stanford Cardinal women's soccer|women's soccer]] teams, as well as the [[Stanford Cardinal women's lacrosse|women's lacrosse]] team. The facility opened in 1973, and featured renovations in 1997 and 2011. In addition to Cardinal matches, the stadium has been used as a practice training ground for the United States [[United States men's national soccer team|men's]] and [[United States women's national soccer team|women's]] national soccer team. The stadium has also been used as a venue for [[Major League Soccer]]'s [[San Jose Earthquakes]] for practices and [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|U.S. Open Cup]] fixtures. The current capacity since the 2011 renovation is 2,952.{{cite web|title=Seating Information and Seating Chart - Laird Q. Cagan Stadium|url=http://www.gostanford.com/sports/2013/4/17/208446870.aspx|website=gostanford.com|accessdate=November 12, 2017|date=April 17, 2013}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.gostanford.com/sports/2013/4/17/208446870.aspx Cagan Stadium] {{Stanford University}} {{Pac-12 Conference soccer venue navbox}} [[Category:Sports venues in Santa Clara County, California]] [[Category:Stanford University buildings and structures]] [[Category:Sports venues in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:College soccer venues in California]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:1973 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1973]]

{{Multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=September 2018}}{{notability|1=Sport|date=September 2018}}}} {{Infobox football league | logo = | pixels = | country = {{ROM}} | confed = [[UEFA]] |founded = 2016 as Liga II
2017 as Liga III | teams = | divisions = 2 | promotion = [[Liga II (women's football)|Liga II]] | relegation = | levels = 3 | domest_cup = [[Romanian Women's Cup]] | confed_cup = | champions = | season = | most_champs= | website = [http://www.frfotbal.ro/index.php?competition_id=98 frfotbal.ro] | current = }} '''Liga III''' is the third-level [[women's association football|women's football]] league in [[Romania]]. It was created starting with the 2016–17 season, when it formally received the name ''Liga II'', following the introduction of ''Superliga'' as the top-tier league, and the subsequent relegation of ''Liga I'' to second-tier. However, as of the 2017–18 season, it was rebranded as ''Liga III'', since the ''Superliga'' brand was dropped altogether, and subsequently ''Liga I'' became the top league, and ''Liga II'' the second.http://www.frfotbal.ro/index.php?competition_id=98 ==Format== In its first season, it had only one series. From the 2017–18 season, two series were played. ==Winners== The following is a list of all Romanian women's third-tier football league winners. The first place is declared the champion of the series, is slated for promotion to Liga II, and is presented with a trophy. Second teams of clubs cannot be promoted if the first team of the club is in the next higher tier. The promoted teams in each series for every year are denoted in italics. Because it is the lowest level in the Romanian Football League, there is no formal relegation. {| class="wikitable" width=750px; !width=5%|Ed. !width=26%|Season !width=23%|Champions !width=23%|Runner-up !width=23%|Third place |- |1 || 2016–17 Liga II || ''Piroș Security Arad'' || ''Atletic Onix Râmnicu Sărat'' || Banat Girls Reșița |- |2 || 2017–18 Liga III, Series I || ''Vulpițele Galbene Roman'' || Nicu Gane Fălticeni || Dream Team București |- |2 || 2017–18 Liga III, Series II || ''Banat Girls Rețița'' || [[CFR Timișoara (women)|CFR 2 Timișoara]] || Independența 2 Baia Mare |} {{Football in Romania}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Football leagues in Romania|Women]] {{Romania-footy-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
The [[Gentlemen v Players]] [[first-class cricket]] fixture was first played in 1806 and, despite many difficulties in the early years, it had by 1840 become an established annual event in the [[Cricket in England|English cricket calendar]]. Apart from the years of the two World Wars, it remained so until 1962. The purpose of the fixture was to match the best of the [[amateur status in first-class cricket|amateur cricketers]] (the [[Gentlemen cricket team|Gentlemen]]) against the best of the paid professionals (the [[Players cricket team|Players]]). The table below summarises the full career record in the fixture of everyone who made their debuts for the Gentlemen team in the matches played to 1840.
==Key== * '''club''' denotes the player's usual team when he represented the Gentlemen (most at the time were MCC members). * '''debut''' denotes the year of the player's debut appearance for the Gentlemen. * '''final''' denotes the year of the player's final appearance for the Gentlemen. * '''M''' denotes the number of '''matches''' in which the player represented the Gentlemen. * '''runs''' denotes the total number of [[run (cricket)|runs]] scored by the player in all his matches for the Gentlemen. * '''HS''' denotes the '''highest score''' made by the player in one [[innings]] when [[batting (cricket)|batting]] for the Gentlemen (* signifies [[not out]]). * '''wkts''' denotes the total number of [[wicket]]s taken by the player in all his matches for the Gentlemen. * '''BB''' denotes the '''best [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]]''' performance by the player in one innings for the Gentlemen (e.g., 3–30 means he took 3 wickets in the innings and conceded 30 runs; to 1840, runs conceded by bowlers are usually unknown, hence "?"). * players are initially listed according to the date of their debut for the Gentlemen. * players in '''bold''' were '''known professionals''' who represented the Gentlemen as "given men" in order to handicap the Players.
==List== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ List of Gentlemen cricketers to 1840 ! style="background:#faecc8"| name ! style="background:#faecc8"| nation ! style="background:#faecc8"| club ! style="background:#faecc8"| debut ! style="background:#faecc8"| final ! style="background:#faecc8"| M ! style="background:#faecc8"| [[Run (cricket)|runs]] ! style="background:#faecc8"| HS ! style="background:#faecc8"| [[Wicket|wkts]] ! style="background:#faecc8"| BB ! class="unsortable" style="background:#faecc8"| references |- |{{sortname|Thomas|Assheton Smith II|Thomas Assheton Smith II}} || {{flag|England}} || [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]] || 1806 || 1806 || 2 || 60 || 48 || 0 || 0–0 || <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/player/20889.html |title=T. A. Smith |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/32/32890/32890.html |title=T. A. Smith |publisher=CricketArchive |accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/32/32890/f_Batting_by_Team.html |title=First-class Batting and Fielding For Each Team by T. revision.comment: Rhododendrites moved page [[Boating magazine]] to [[List of boating magazines]]: page is a list, renaming (hopefully uncontroversially)
revision.text:
A '''boating magazine''' is a publication whose main topic is boating, new boat reviews, boat motors and watersports. They can be aimed at different water sports enthusiasts including: cruisers, fishers, skiers, sailors, racers, et cetera.
Boating magazines include: * ''[[Australian Sailing magazine|Australian Sailing]]'' * ''[[Boating (magazine)|Boating]]'' * ''[[Boating Life]]'' * ''[[BoatUS]] Magazine'' * ''[[Chesapeake Bay Magazine]]'' * ''[[The Ensign (USPS magazine)|The Ensign]]'' (United States Power Squadrons magazine) * ''[[Lakeland Boating]]'' *''[[Northeast Boating Magazine]]'' *''[[On the Water (magazine)|On the Water]]'' * ''[[Sea History (magazine)|Sea History]]'' * ''[[Yaahting]]'' (parody) *'' [[Yachting World]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Lists of magazines|Boating magazines]] [[Category:Sports magazines]] [[Category:Boating magazines|*]] [[Category:Maritime magazines]]

'''Manchester Cricket Club''' was founded in 1816 and was a direct forerunner of [[Lancashire County Cricket Club]], founded in 1864. Manchester had [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match status]] and is classified as such by substantial sources from 1844 to 1864, after which it was superseded by the county club and ceased to be an important team in its own right.<ref>{{cite book |last=ACS |first= |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A Guide to Important Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles 1709 – 1863|year=1981 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |isbn=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=ACS |first= |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A Guide to First-Class Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles |year=1982 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |isbn=}}</ref>
==History== Cricket may not have reached [[Lancashire]] until the 18th century. The earliest known reference to cricket being played in the county is in 1781.<ref>Bowen, p.266.</ref> In 1816, Manchester Cricket Club was founded and soon became representative of Lancashire as a county in the same way that [[Sheffield Cricket Club]] and [[Nottingham Cricket Club]] represented [[Yorkshire]] and [[Nottinghamshire]].
Manchester played mostly against opponents from the north of England and its matches from July 1844 until 1864 (including some in which the team was styled "Lancashire") have important status per the ACS classification. Ten of these were against Sheffield, who in three of them were called Yorkshire. Other opponents included [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]], [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] and [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC). On 23, 24 & 25 July 1849, the Sheffield and Manchester clubs played each other at the [[Hyde Park Ground]] in [[Sheffield]] and the fixture was called "Yorkshire ''versus'' Lancashire". As such, it was the first match to involve a Lancashire county team and also, therefore, the first "[[Roses Match]]". Yorkshire won by 5 wickets.
A noted Manchester player was [[John Sherman (cricketer)|John Sherman]]. On 27 July 1852, he made his final top-class appearance for Manchester against Sheffield at the Hyde Park Ground. His career had spanned 44 seasons from his debut at [[Lord's Old Ground]] on 20 September 1809 when he played for Beauclerk's XI against Ladbroke's XI. His was the longest career span, equalled only by [[W. G. Grace]].
In their early years, the club played their cricket on land adjacent to the [[Manchester Botanical Garden]] and leased from the [[de Trafford baronets|Trafford family]]. In 1856, [[Sir Humphrey de Trafford]] identified this land as being an ideal location for the planned [[Art Treasures Exhibition, Manchester 1857|Manchester Art and Treasures Exhibition]]. Sir Humphrey was a member of the Executive Committee planning the exhibition who offered Manchester Cricket Club £500 in compensation for the remainder of their lease. The club, however, insisted on a figure of £1,000 and agreed to vacate the site ahead of the 1857 season, moving to the inferior location (as it was further from transport links and only accessible via a long rough track) that subsequently became [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground]], the home of Lancashire cricket ever since.
[[Lancashire County Cricket Club]] was formally constituted on 12 January 1864 at a meeting of thirteen Lancashire cricket clubs in Manchester. In 1865, the new club joined the [[County Championship]] and played its initial [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] against [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] at Old Trafford on 20, 21 and 22 July. The Manchester club was superseded by the county club and ceased to have [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match status]] in its own right.
==Important matches== The following is a list of matches played by Manchester, sometimes styled Lancashire:<ref name=CAL>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/1/1629/First-Class_Matches.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=First-class matches played by Lancashire |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=CAM>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/0/198/First-Class_Matches.html |publisher=CricketArchive |title=First-class matches played by Manchester |accessdate=13 October 2012}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! date ! match title ! venue |- | 4 July 1844 | Manchester v Yorkshire | [[Moss Lane Cricket Ground|Moss Lane]], [[Manchester]] |- | 3 July 1845 | Manchester v Yorkshire | Moss Lane, Manchester |- | 28 August 1845 | Manchester v Yorkshire | Moss Lane, Manchester |- | 29 June 1846 | Sheffield v Manchester | [[Hyde Park Ground]], [[Sheffield]] |- | 29 July 1846 | Manchester v Sheffield | Moss Lane, Manchester |- | 8 June 1848 | Manchester v Sheffield | [[Botanical Gardens Cricket Ground|Botanical Gardens]], Manchester |- | 10 July 1848 | Sheffield v Manchester | Hyde Park Ground, Sheffield |- | 23 July 1849 | Yorkshire v Lancashire | Hyde Park Ground, Sheffield |- | 2 August 1849 | Lancashire v Yorkshire | Botanical Gardens, Manchester |- | 28 July 1851 | Yorkshire v Lancashire | Hyde Park Ground, Sheffield |- | 21 August 1851 | Lancashire v Yorkshire | Botanical Gardens, Manchester |- | 24 May 1852 | MCC v Manchester | [[Lord's Cricket Ground]], [[St John's Wood]] |- | 16 July 1852 | Manchester v Sheffield | Botanical Gardens, Manchester |- | 26 July 1852 | Sheffield v Manchester | Hyde Park Ground, Sheffield |- | 20 July 1854 | Manchester v Sheffield | Botanical Gardens, Manchester |- | 3 September 1857 | Manchester v Surrey | [[G. P. Codie's Ground]], [[Eccles, Greater Manchester|Eccles]] |- | 2 September 1858 | Manchester v Sussex | G. P. Codie's Ground, Eccles |}
==Records (important matches only)== * Highest team total: 210 v Sheffield, Hyde Park Ground, Sheffield, 1846 * Lowest team total: 42 v [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]], [[Lord's Cricket Ground]], 1852 * Highest individual innings: 87[[not out|*]] by [[Samuel Baldwinson]] v Sheffield, [[Moss Lane Cricket Ground|Moss Lane]], Manchester, 1846 * Best bowling: 7-31 by [[John Wisden]] v [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]], [[G. P. Codie's Ground]], [[Eccles, Greater Manchester|Eccles]], 1857

{{DEFAULTSORT:Manchester Cricket Club}} [[Category:1816 establishments in England]] [[Category:Cricket in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Cricket in Lancashire]] [[Category:English club cricket teams]] [[Category:English cricket in the 19th century]] [[Category:Former senior cricket clubs]] [[Category:History of Lancashire]] [[Category:Sport in Manchester]] [[Category:Sports clubs established in the 1810s]]

{{Infobox sport | name = Modern pentathlon | image = Modern Pentathlon 2004 Olympics.jpg | alt = | imagesize = | caption = Conclusion of the [[Modern pentathlon at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's|men's event]] at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] | union = [[Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne]] (UIPM) | nickname = | first = | firstlabel = | region = | registered = | clubs = | contact = No | team = | mgender = | type = [[Fencing]], [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[show jumping]], [[shooting sport|shooting]], and [[running]] sport | equipment = | venue = | olympic = | world = | paralympic = }} [[File:Modern Pentathlon Logo.jpg|thumb|UIPM Modern Pentathlon logo]] The '''modern pentathlon''' is an [[Summer Olympics|Olympic]] sport that comprises five different events; [[fencing (sport)|fencing]] (one-touch épée), [[freestyle swimming]] (200m), equestrian [[show jumping]] (15 jumps), and a final combined event of [[pistol shooting]] and [[cross country running]] (3200m). This last event is now referred to as the laser-run, since it alternates four legs of laser pistol shooting followed by an 800m run (for 3200m in total). The event is inspired by the [[Ancient Olympic pentathlon|traditional pentathlon]] held during the ancient Olympics; as the original events were patterned on the skills needed by an ideal Greek soldier of the era, the modern pentathlon is similarly patterned on events representing the skills needed by cavalry behind enemy lines.
The sport has been a core sport of the Olympic Games since 1912 despite attempts to remove it.<ref name="ioc-planning">{{cite news |url=http://www.thesportjournal.org/article/special-edition-sport-journal-ioc-planning-drop-modern-pentathlon-olympic-games |title=Special Edition: Refuting IOC's Plan to End Modern Pentathlon Competition |last= |first= |date=Fall 2002 |work=The Sport Journal |accessdate=2012-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605032621/http://thesportjournal.org/article/special-edition-sport-journal-ioc-planning-drop-modern-pentathlon-olympic-games |archivedate=2012-06-05 |df= }}</ref> A world championships for modern pentathlon has been held annually since 1949.
Originally the competition took place over four or five days; [[Modern pentathlon at the 1996 Summer Olympics|in 1996]] a one-day format was adopted in an effort to be more audience-friendly.<ref name="nyt"/> Modern pentathlon, despite its long Olympic history, has had to justify its inclusion in the modern Olympic Games several times. On February 11, 2013 in Lausanne, the IOC confirmed modern pentathlon once again as one of the 25 core sports of the Olympic program through to 2020. The governing body, [[Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne]] (UIPM), administers the international sport in more than 90 countries in all the continents of the world.<ref name="ioc-planning"/>
==History== The foundation of the modern pentathlon is disputed. On the one hand, Baron [[Pierre de Coubertin]], the founder of the [[Olympic Games|modern Olympic Games]], claimed authorship.<ref name="nyt"> {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/27/sports/olympics/27pentathlon.html?_r=1&scp=4&sq=%22John%20Branch%22&st=cse |title=Modern Pentathlon Gets a Little Less Penta |last=Branch |first=John |date=November 26, 2008 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-11-27}}</ref> On the other hand, [[Viktor Balck]], the President of the Organizing Committee for the 1912 Games, showed that he made use of the long tradition of Swedish military multi-sports events, to create a manageable modern pentathlon.<ref>Sandra Heck: Von Spielenden Soldaten und kämpfenden Athleten. Die Genese des Modernen Fünfkampfes. Göttingen: V & R Unipress. 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-8471-0201-4}}</ref>
The name derives from the Greek ''péntathlon'' "contest of five events".<ref name="nyt"/> The addition of ''modern'' to the name distinguishes it from the [[Ancient Olympic pentathlon|original pentathlon]] of the [[ancient Olympic Games]], which consisted of the [[Stadion (running race)|''stadion'' foot race]], [[wrestling]], [[long jump]], [[javelin throw|javelin]], and [[discus throw|discus]]. As the events of the ancient pentathlon were modeled after the skills of the ideal soldier to defend a castle of that time, Coubertin created the contest to simulate the experience of a 19th-century [[cavalry]] soldier behind enemy lines: he must ride an unfamiliar horse, fight enemies with pistol and sword, swim, and run to return to his own soldiers.<ref name="nyt"/> In the 1912 Games, with only officers competing, they were, however, permitted to use their own horses. Up to the 1952 Olympics the ordinary cavalry soldier was considered a [[professional athlete]], as he was riding and training horses for a living, while the officer was the [[amateur]]. As long as there was no official international federation for Modern Pentathlon an IOC committee was set up for the sport making use of the expertise of IOC members.<ref>[[Arnd Krüger]]: Forgotton Decisions. The IOC on the Eve of World War I, in: ''Olympika'' 6 (1997), 85 – 98. (http://www.la84foundation.org/SportsLibrary/Olympika/Olympika_1997/olympika0601g.pdf)</ref>
The event was first held at the [[1912 Olympic Games]], and was won by Swedish athlete [[Gösta Lilliehöök]]. The modern pentathlon has been on the Olympic program continuously since 1912. A team event was added to the Olympic Games [[Modern pentathlon at the 1952 Summer Olympics|in 1952]] and discontinued [[Modern pentathlon at the 1992 Summer Olympics|in 1992]]. After much lobby work of the President of the German Modern Pentathlon Federation Prof. Wilhelm Henze, women were for the first time admitted on a trial basis at the World Championships in San Antonio in 1977, and at the official world championships in 1981.<ref>Uta Engels: "Now the Problem: Modern Pentathlon for Ladies." Zur Rolle Prof. Dr. Peter-Wilhem Henzes bei der Entwicklung des Modernen Frauenfünfkampfes, in: [[Arnd Krüger]] & Bernd Wedemeyer (eds.): ''Aus Biographien Sportgeschichte lernen. Festschrift zum 90. Geburtstag von Prof. Dr. Wilhelm Henze''. Hoya: Niedersächsisches Institut für Sportgeschichte 2000, S. 47 -66. {{ISBN|3-932423-07-0}}</ref> An event for women was added [[Modern pentathlon at the 2000 Summer Olympics|in 2000]].<ref name="nyt"/> A World Championship is held every year. The competitions include Men and Women's Individual and Team event together with relay events for Men and Women and, since 2010, a mixed relay event.
==Competition format== Athletes gain points for their performance in each event and scores are combined to give the overall total. This is similar to the procedure for the [[decathlon]] in [[track and field athletics]]. However, in the modern pentathlon, starting times for the last event (cross country running before 2009; combined laser pistol shooting and cross-country running since 2009),<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/olympic_games/7745671.stm Pentathlon change irks Livingston], [[BBC]], 24 November 2008</ref> are staggered so that the first person to cross the finish line is the winner. Before the last event competitors are ranked according to their score from the other disciplines and given start times accordingly, with the leader going first, and other starting times being dependent on the number of points already scored. The first person to cross the finish line, therefore, will be the overall points leader and win the pentathlon. This method of finishing the competition may have been inspired by similar formats in winter sports; the [[Gundersen method]], for example, details a means by which a similar finish is achieved in the [[Nordic combined]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}}
<gallery> File:Sgt. Nathan Schrimsher competes in Modern Pentathlon at Rio Olympic Games photos by Tim Hipps, IMCOM Public Affairs (28453220414).jpg|Fencing File:Sgt. Nathan Schrimsher swims at Rio Games (29036132652).jpg|Swimming File:Alice Sotero - Rio 2016.jpg|Riding File:Sgt. Nathan Schrimsher competes in Modern Pentathlon at Rio Olympic Games photos by Tim Hipps, IMCOM Public Affairs (28546133194).jpg|Shooting
File:Joe Choong Rio2016.jpg|Running </gallery>
* The [[fencing]] discipline uses the [[épée]]. The competition is a [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]], meaning each competitor will face all the other competitors once. Each match lasts up to one minute; the first fencer to score a hit wins instantly. Double hits are not counted. If neither scores within one minute, they both lose the match. * The swimming discipline is a 200 m [[Freestyle swimming|freestyle]] race. Until the 2000 Olympics, the distance was 300 metres.<ref name="goodluck"> {{cite news |url=http://www.goodluckbeijing.com.cn/en/archives/sports/2007-03-10/2365.html |title=Modern Pentathlon |date=2007-03-10 |publisher='Good Luck Beijing' |accessdate=2008-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006203852/http://www.goodluckbeijing.com.cn/en/archives/sports/2007-03-10/2365.html |archivedate=2008-10-06 |df= }} </ref> Competitors are seeded in heats according to their fastest time over the distance. * The riding discipline involves [[show jumping]] over a 350–450 m course with 12 to 15 obstacles. Competitors are paired with horses in a draw 20 minutes before the start of the event. <ref group=Note>This unusual skill—the riding of a random horse is also used in the US for college equestrian team competitions and in club IEA horse back riding.</ref> Currently, this is the only Olympic sport that awards a medal to the participating horse{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}. * Until 2009, the shooting discipline involved using a 4.5 mm ([[Pellet (air gun)|.177 cal]]) [[air pistol]] in the standing position from 10 metres distance at a stationary target. The format was that of the [[10 metre air pistol]] competition: each competitor had 20 shots, with 40 seconds allowed for each shot. In 2009, the combined event, now referred to as the laser-run, was born. This involved a combination of the running and shooting events so that each competitor ran three 1000 m laps, each prefaced by hitting five targets with a pistol. Beginning with the Rancho Mirage World Cup (Feb 2011), the pistols changed to a laser instead of an actual projectile. There is a slight delay between the trigger pull and the laser firing, simulating the time it would take for a pellet to clear the muzzle.<ref name="slate">{{cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/five_ring_circus/2012/08/12/modern_pentathlon_2012_olympics_can_lasers_save_the_olympics_weirdest_sport_.html |title=Can Lasers Save the Modern Pentathlon? |date=2012-08-12}}</ref> * The running discipline involved a 3 km [[cross country running|cross-country]] race until 2009 when it combined with the shooting event. From the start of the 2013 season, the laser-run has changed again to consist of four 800m laps each prefaced by laser shooting at five targets. This change is intended to restore some of the importance of the shooting skill felt to have been lost in the original 2009 combined event. Until the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympics]], the distance was 4 kilometres.<ref name="goodluck"/>
The laser-run is similar to the [[biathlon]] at the [[Winter Olympic Games]], which combines [[cross-country skiing (sport)|cross-country skiing]] with [[Shooting sports#Rifle|rifle shooting]]. However, whereas biathletes carry their rifles while skiing, pentathletes do not carry their pistols while running.
The laser-run has been criticized as altering too radically the nature of the skills required. ''[[The New York Times]]'' asked whether the name ought to be changed to "tetrathlon" given that two of the five disciplines had been combined into a single event.<ref name="nyt"/>
In the new format, in each of the four rounds of firing, athletes have to successfully shoot five targets, loading the laser gun after each shot. They resume running once they have five successful hits, or once the maximum shooting time of 50 seconds has expired. Misses are not penalised.<ref name="nyt"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pentathlon.org/images/Rules/ii%205%20combined%20event%2017%201%202012final.pdf|title=Rules for Combined Event Running and Shooting|publisher=UIPM|accessdate=2012-08-12}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The new format maintains the principle that the overall winner will be the first to cross the finish line.<ref name="nyt"/>
==See also== *[[Pentathlon]] *[[List of Olympic medalists in modern pentathlon]] *[[Modern pentathlon at the Summer Olympics]] *[[World Modern Pentathlon Championships]]

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Newport Stadium | nickname = Spytty Park | image = [[File:Newport Stadium - larger.jpg|300px|centre]] | caption = View of the grandstand from the ''Shed''
([[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] vs a [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] XI, [[2003–04 Newport County A.F.C. season|31 Mar 2004]]) | location = [[Lliswerry]], [[Newport, Wales|Newport]] NP19 4PT | coordinates = {{coord|51|34|26|N|2|57|34|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | opened = 1994 | closed = | owner = [[Newport City Council]] | operator = Newport City Council | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Pound sterling|£]]7 million | architect = | tenants = [[Newport City F.C.|Newport City]]
Newport Harriers A.C.
[[Newport County A.F.C.]] (1994–2012) | expanded = 2004 | seating_capacity = 5,058 (3,246 seated) | record_attendance = 4,616 }} [[Image:Newport Stadium.JPG|300px|thumb|right|Newport Stadium grandstand entrance]] '''Newport Stadium''', also known as '''Spytty Park''', is an [[association football]] and [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] [[stadium]] in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[South Wales]]. It is the home of [[Newport City F.C.|Newport City]] football club and Newport Harriers Athletic Club. It was previously also used for home matches by [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]] and [[Albion Rovers F.C. (Newport)|Albion Rovers]] football clubs. Newport County continue to use the stadium as a base for youth teams and senior squad training. ==Facilities== The stadium is owned and managed by [[Newport City Council]] and is part of the [[Newport International Sports Village]], which includes the [[Wales National Velodrome]]. It was upgraded to [[Conference National]] standard for football and had a capacity of 5,058 prior to Newport County relocating to [[Rodney Parade]] in 2012.[http://www.newport-county.co.uk/stadium_details.html Stadium details] Newport County The stadium can accommodate international-standard track and field athletic events and is of Class 1 standard. The stadium floodlighting can achieve up to an average of 500 [[Lux]].[http://www.newport.gov.uk/_dc/index.cfm?fuseaction=leisure.centres&contentid=devxp001383 Newport Stadium at NISV] Newport City Council ==Layout== The stadium has two covered stands along the touchlines of the [[Association football pitch|pitch]]. The west stand is all-seated with a capacity of 1,100 spectators. The east stand is a 1,600-capacity covered standing [[Terrace (stadium)|terrace]], commonly referred to as ''The Shed''. An uncovered standing terrace also exists at the north end. The stadium is approached from Spytty Road and has a large spectator car park. ==Temporary and demountable stands== When Newport County played [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in the [[2001–02 FA Cup]], a temporary all-seated stand was erected behind the goal at the north end in front of the terrace – at that time there was only the west stand and a very small north terrace. When Newport County played Swansea City in the [[2006–07 FA Cup]], a temporary stand was erected behind the goal at the south end. In 2011 further all-seated uncovered demountable stands were erected behind each goal: A 949-seater stand at the south end and a 1,197-seater stand in front of the north terrace. This took the total capacity of the stadium to 5,058 with 3,246 seated. ==Football attendance records== The record attendance at the ground without temporary stands is 4,300 (a capacity crowd at the time) against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the [[2003–04 Newport County A.F.C. season|2003–04 season]]. With the addition of a temporary stand, the record attendance stands at 4,616, set for a FA Cup match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 11 November 2006. ==References== {{commons category}} {{reflist}} {{Newport County A.F.C.}} {{Newport}} [[Category:Stadiums in Newport, Wales]] [[Category:Football venues in Wales]] [[Category:Newport County A.F.C.]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Wales]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Wales]]
