{{Infobox venue |stadium_name=Notre Dame Stadium |nickname=''The House That Rockne Built'' |image=Notre-dame-stadium-small.jpg |caption=Notre Dame Stadium in July 2009 |address=2010 Moose Krause Circle |location=[[Notre Dame, Indiana]] |coordinates={{Coord|41.698|N|86.234|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} |broke_ground={{Start date and age|1929}} |opened={{Start date and age|1930|10|4}} |owner=[[University of Notre Dame]] |operator=University of Notre Dame |surface=Natural grass (1930–2013)
[[FieldTurf]] (2014–present) |construction_cost=[[United States dollar|$]]750,000 |architect=[[Osborn Engineering]] |project_manager= |structural engineer= |services engineer= |general_contractor=Sollitt Construction Company |main_contractors= |former_names= |seating_capacity=54,000 (1930–1965)
59,075 (1966–1996)
80,225 (1997)
80,012 (1998–1999)
80,232 (2000)
80,795 (2001–2016)
77,622{{cite web|title=The Fighting Irish|url=https://twitter.com/fightingirish/status/904026724723286016|website=Twitter|accessdate=18 November 2017|date=2 September 2017|quote=@NDFootball opens the enhanced Notre Dame Stadium to a packed crowd of 77,622.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511214034/https://twitter.com/fightingirish/status/904026724723286016|archivedate=11 May 2018|df=}} (2017–present) |tenants=[[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame Fighting Irish]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
(1930–present) |}} '''Notre Dame Stadium''' is an outdoor [[college football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Notre Dame, Indiana|Notre Dame]], [[Indiana]], the home field of the [[University of Notre Dame]] [[Fighting Irish football|Fighting Irish]]. It is located on the university's campus and also hosts commencement. Opened {{Years or months ago|1930|10}} on October 4, [[1930 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1930]], the stadium [[seating capacity]] was nearly 60,000 for decades. More than 21,000 seats were added for the [[1997 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1997]] season, which increased the capacity to over 80,000. After the Campus Crossroads renovation, the seat number decreased to 77,622. The playing surface was changed to [[FieldTurf]] in [[2014 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|2014]], after 84 seasons on natural grass. ==History== The stadium opened its gates on October 4, 1930, replacing [[Cartier Field]]. The total cost of construction exceeded [[United States dollar|$]]750,000 and the original [[seating capacity]] was 54,000. Head coach [[Knute Rockne]] played a key role in its design, keeping the space between the playing field and the stands to a minimum. The stadium is patterned, on a smaller scale, after [[Michigan Stadium]], the main difference being the tunnel location. In 1929, plans were started by [[Osborn Engineering]] of [[Cleveland]], selected for their experience in designing [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] and [[Fenway Park]]. The original stadium held 59,075 people, measured a half-mile (800 m) in circumference, stood {{convert|45|ft|0}} high, and featured a glass-enclosed press box rising {{convert|60|ft|0}} above ground level. Initial stands reached 55 rows.{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2015/09/new_stadiums_old_gray_lady_and_others|title=New stadiums: Old Gray Lady and others – StadiumDB.com|author=|date=|website=stadiumdb.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925161556/http://stadiumdb.com/news/2015/09/new_stadiums_old_gray_lady_and_others|archivedate=2015-09-25|df=}} The building was built by the Sollitt Construction Company of South Bend. Earth preparation began in the fall of 1929, but due to an unusually cold fall and winter, above ground construction did not begin until April 2, 1930. This building was effectively built in six months. Over two million bricks were used in the construction of the walls and the concrete was placed in a monolithic continuous placement by section. There were over 300 workers on the site at most times and they worked five 10-hour days and one six-hour day on Saturdays. The average worker was paid one dollar a day plus lunch with the more skilled workers earning up to five dollars a day.Notre Dame archives [[File:The Stadium, Notre Dame, Indiana (63329).jpg|left|thumbnail|Notre Dame stadium between circa 1930 and 1945]] The construction of the stadium project was brought to a head by the actions of Knute Rockne. The 1928 season had not been a stellar one for the football team, but the net profits from football for that season approached $500,000. Rockne was frustrated with the slow and cautious [[Congregation of Holy Cross|Holy Cross]] priests and their decision making process about spending money on the new stadium. Rockne could not believe that a decision could not be made when there was such a large amount of money in the bank. Because of this and a number of other issues, Rockne submitted his resignation to Father O’Donnell, the president of the university. O’Donnell knew of Rockne’s history of submitting his resignations and he also knew that nothing would ever completely satisfy Rockne. O’Donnell was willing to find a compromise but was also unwilling to put the university in debt to finance the stadium. He knew that the excess receipts from 1928 season and the projected receipts from playing all the away games in [[1929 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1929]] on neutral fields would bring adequate cash into the university to finance the construction of the stadium. O’Donnell also devised the scheme to finance 240 six-person “reserved box seats”. This precursor of the [[personal seat license]] would allow the buyer to purchase tickets at face value and guarantee the same prime location for 10 years for an investment of $3,000 between the 45-yard lines, $2,500 between the 45 and 35-yard line and $2,000 between the 35 and the 25-yard line. The university raised over $150,000 on this idea alone.Being Catholic, Being American The Notre Dame Story, 1842–1934, Robert E Burns, University of Notre Dame Press, Notre Dame Indiana,1999 The Irish played their first game in the new stadium in [[1930 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1930]] on October 4, beating [[SMU Mustangs football|SMU]] 20–14. The first Notre Dame touchdown in the stadium was scored by [[Joe_Savoldi|"Jumping Joe" Savoldi]] on a 98-yard kickoff return. The official dedication was a week later on October 11 against [[Navy Midshipmen football|Navy]], and Savoldi scored three touchdowns and was cited as [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19301012&id=sG8hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DIgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2617,2207104&hl=en "the first hero in the lore of Notre Dame Stadium."] As originally built, the stadium seated 54,000 people. However, with temporary bleachers, it could hold as many as 61,000 people. By 1966, its capacity increased to 59,075, mainly by changing the average seat width from {{convert|18|to|17|in|cm|1}}. In 1997, 21,000 new seats were added to the stadium, bringing the [[seating capacity]] to the present 80,795. The playing surface had always been natural grass through [[2013 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|2013]], but it was announced on April 12, [[2014 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|2014]], that after the commencement weekend, the playing field would be replaced with [[FieldTurf]], an infilled [[artificial turf]].{{cite press release |url=http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/041214aac.html |title=Synthetic Turf to be Installed in Notre Dame Stadium by 2014 Football Season |publisher=Notre Dame Athletics |date=April 12, 2014 |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521031659/http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/041214aac.html |archivedate=May 21, 2014 |df= }} Notre Dame athletic director [[Jack Swarbrick]], in making the announcement, cited recent difficulties with maintaining an acceptable grass surface, and added that the change would allow the stadium to be used for football practices and non-football events. During 2013, the university replaced the grass surface four times, including twice during the [[2013 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|football season]].{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/10954073/notre-dame-fighting-irish-selling-stadium-turf-sections-150 |title=Notre Dame sells turf for $150 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=''[[ESPN.com]]'' |date=May 19, 2014 |accessdate=May 19, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140520143654/http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/10954073/notre-dame-fighting-irish-selling-stadium-turf-sections-150 |archivedate=May 20, 2014 |df= }} [[File:Notre Dame Stadium Panorama.jpg|thumb|Notre Dame Stadium Panorama]] On January 29, 2014, the university announced plans to attach three new buildings to the stadium, totaling more than 750,000 square feet in expansions and costing about $400 million, with a timetable of 33 months for completion. According to a published statement by university president [[John I. Jenkins]], "the integrated nature of this project will maintain the compact [[walkability]] of campus, facilitate deeper connection and collaboration across the various units of the university, and offer an exciting addition" to the campus.{{cite web|title=Notre Dame Spending $400 Million on Football Stadium Renovation|url=http://www.newsmax.com/US/notre-dame-football-stadium-renovations/2014/01/29/id/549796|work=Article|publisher=Newsmax|accessdate=29 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202103657/http://www.newsmax.com/US/notre-dame-football-stadium-renovations/2014/01/29/id/549796|archivedate=2 February 2014|df=}} The FieldTurf installation, as scheduled, began after Commencement Weekend on May 16–18, and the university sold {{convert|2|by|5|ft|cm|0|sing=on}} sections of the old turf to the public for $150 each. ==Structure and architecture== ===Lighting=== Prior to the 1997 expansion, Notre Dame Stadium lacked permanent field lights. In [[1982 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1982]], portable lighting by [[Musco Lighting]] was used for the first night game in the stadium's history on September 18 versus Michigan. Permanent lights were installed as part of the expansion. The lights were paid for by [[NBC Sports|NBC]], which has held the exclusive television rights to all home games since [[1991 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1991]]. The permanent lights were added primarily to ensure sufficient lighting for mid-afternoon games in November; the university's agreements with NBC from 1991 to 2010 stipulated that there be no home night games.{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/sports/colleges/articles/2008/06/19/20080619nbcnd.html|title=Notre Dame, NBC agree to deal through 2015|author=|date=|website=www.azcentral.com}} However, the stadium hosted its first night game in 21 years on October 22, 2011 when the Irish hosted USC.{{cite web|url=http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/sched/nd-m-footbl-sched.html|title=Notre Dame Football Official Schedule :: Notre Dame Football :: UND.COM :: The Official Site of Notre Dame Athletics|author=|date=|website=www.und.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905055203/http://www.und.com/sports/m-footbl/sched/nd-m-footbl-sched.html|archivedate=2015-09-05|df=}} It was announced in 2015 that Musco would be installing a LED field lighting system as part of the 2014–2017 stadium renovation and expansion project.{{cite web|url=http://www.musco.com/news/press-nd.html|title=Musco Press Release University of Notre Dame - Musco Sports Lighting -|author=|date=|website=www.musco.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108075422/http://musco.com/news/press-nd.html|archivedate=2016-01-08|df=}} ==="Touchdown Jesus"=== [[File:TDJesus.jpg|thumb|"Touchdown Jesus" is visible from inside the stadium]] The stadium is known for its view of "Touchdown Jesus", a nickname given to the large mural entitled ''The Word of Life'' by [[Millard Sheets]] of the [[Resurrection of Jesus|resurrected Jesus]].University of Notre Dame Hesburgh Libraries, [http://www.library.nd.edu/about/history/mosaic.shtml Hesburgh (Main) Library ''Word of Life'' Mural] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060807002011/http://www.library.nd.edu/about/history/mosaic.shtml |date=2006-08-07 }} Installed in [[1964 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1964]] on the [[Hesburgh Library]], the mosaic wall looms over the stadium. The mural's nickname is derived from Jesus' upraised arms, which are similar in appearance to the raised arms of a referee signifying a [[touchdown]]. The expansion of the stadium in the late 1990s partially obscured the view of the mural from the playing field. ''The Word of Life'' mural was a gift of Mr. and Mrs. Howard V. Phalin of [[Winnetka, Illinois]]. ===Campus Crossroads=== [[File:Duncan Student Center.jpg|thumb|The Duncan Student Center, part of Campus Crossroads]] In January 2014, the University announced a $400 million enhancement of the stadium, the Campus Crossroads project. This expansion features 3, 8-story high buildings, on the west, south, and east sides of the stadium. The expansion added more than 750,000 square feet of teaching, research, and performance space. The enhancement added new premium stadium seats. The three buildings are called the Duncan Student Center on the west, O'Neill Hall on the south, and Corbett Family Hall on the east. The project was completed in January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/local/notre-dame-puts-finishing-touches-on-million-campus-crossroads-project/article_476c56be-5f31-5d87-b7ef-f1492acf633f.html|title=Notre Dame puts finishing touches on $400 million Campus Crossroads project|last=Tribune|first=Caleb Bauer South Bend|work=South Bend Tribune|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} ==Attendance== Prior to [[1966 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1966]], attendance figures were based on an actual count of patrons through the gates. The largest crowd to attend a home game prior to expansion was 61,296 in [[1962 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1962]], against [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] on October 6. Since 1966, attendance figures have been based on paid admissions with a fixed number of tickets available, accounting for the familiar 59,075 figure through the [[1996 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1996]] season. Until [[Ara Parseghian]] arrived as coach at Notre Dame in [[1964 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1964]], sellouts were not the norm. Since then, tickets for Notre Dame football have been notoriously hard to come by. As of the end of the [[2015 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|2015]] season, there have been 249 consecutive sellouts at Notre Dame Stadium, and 294 sellouts in the past 295 games dating back to 1964. The lone exception was a [[1973 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1973]] game against [[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]] which had been moved midseason by ABC to [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving Day]] and was played with the students absent. The announced attendance was 57,235. Attendance at all five home games in [[1965 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1965]] exceeded 59,000 as well. [[File:Ndstadium basilica dome tdjesus.jpg|thumb|A view from the east side of the Notre Dame Stadium showing (from left to right) the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, the Golden Dome atop the Administration Building and the Hesburgh Library with the mural of "Touchdown Jesus"]] The official capacity was listed at 80,225 when the stadium was first expanded. A subsequent computer revision put it at 80,012 in [[1998 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|1998]] and 80,232 in 2000. Sideline bleachers, which had been removed during expansion, were put back in after a few years, bringing the figure to its present 80,795 in [[2001 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|2001]]. In January 2014 the University of Notre Dame announced the campus crossroads project. A $400 million renovation would add luxury boxes and increase the stadium's capacity to around 85,000, but after the project was completed the seats were made wider and the number decreased to 77,622.{{cite web|last1=Columnist|first1=Bill Moor Tribune|title=Seats are two inches wider at new Notre Dame Stadium. Yes, it's a big difference.|url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/local/seats-are-two-inches-wider-at-new-notre-dame-stadium/article_2e41b22a-96a1-57bb-be14-a3cf3bd25acc.html|website=South Bend Tribune|language=en}} The project began after the conclusion of the 2014 football season and finished in time for the 2017 season. ==Other events== The stadium is scheduled to host the [[2019 NHL Winter Classic]] on New Years' Day between the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] and [[Boston Bruins]]. On October 20, 2018, the stadium hosted [[Garth Brooks]] as the very first concert in the stadium. It is the first stop on his stadium tour, and it was also announced during the concert that he would also end his tour at Notre Dame Stadium. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.und.com/facilities/notre-dame-stadium.html Notre Dame Stadium] {{Notre Dame Fighting Irish football navbox}} {{University of Notre Dame}} {{NCAA Division I FBS independent football venue navbox}} {{Indiana college football venues}} [[Category:1930 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:American football venues in Indiana]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Notre Dame Fighting Irish football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1930]] [[Category:University of Notre Dame buildings and structures]]
